clinical_study.brief_title: Air Barrier System for the Reduction of Airborne Colony-forming Units During Total Shoulder Arthroplasty
clinical_study.official_title: Air Barrier System for the Reduction of Airborne Particulate and Colony-forming Units (CFU) During Total Shoulder Arthroplasty.

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this study is to determine whether the Air Barrier System device reduces airborne colony-forming units (e.g., bacteria) present at a surgery site during total shoulder arthroplasty surgeries.

detailed_description.textblock: The Air Barrier System (ABS) is a device that uses localized clean air flow to shield a surgery site from ambient airborne contamination. This study examines the hypothesis that the ABS can reduce the presence of airborne CFU and particles at the surgery site during total arthroplasty surgery.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.description: Inter-arm comparison of CFU counts taken during both the Control arm and ABS arm
Inter-arm comparison of particle counts taken during both the Control arm and ABS arm.

arm_group.description: In the control arm, the ABS device will be placed as usual on the patient, but the airflow will NOT be activated. Only the technician in the room will be aware whether the device the device is turned on or not.

In the experimental (interventional) arm, the ABS device will be placed as usual on the patient, and the airflow will be activated. Only the technician in the room will be aware whether the device is turned on or not.

intervention.description: The Air Barrier System will be deployed onto the surgical field, but the airflow will not be activated, so this is a sham control comparator.

The Air Barrier System is a device that uses localized clean air flow to shield a surgery site from ambient airborne microorganisms that are shed into the air from people present in the operating room.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Candidate for total shoulder arthroplasty
Exclusion Criteria:
- Prior history of infection
- Revision surgery
- Screens positive for MRSA
